{{Infobox website | name = Consortium of Online Public Access Catalogues (COPAC) | logo = [[File:Jisc_logo.png]] | caption = Copac is funded by [[Jisc]], to deliver a service to the UK community on the basis of an agreement with [[Research Libraries UK]] (RLUK) | url = {{URL|copac.jisc.ac.uk}} | commercial = | type = [[Union catalog]]
[[Bibliographic database]] | language = English | owner = [[Jisc]]
[[Research Libraries UK]] | launch date = | current status = Active }} '''Copac''' (originally an [[acronym]] of '''C'''onsortium of '''O'''nline '''P'''ublic '''A'''ccess '''C'''atalogues) is a [[union catalogue]] which provides free access to the merged online catalogues of many major [[research library|research libraries]] and specialist libraries in the United Kingdom and Ireland, plus the [[British Library]], the [[National Library of Scotland]] and the [[National Library of Wales]]. It has over 40 million records from around 90 libraries,{{when|date=March 2018}} representing a wide range of materials across all subject areas. Copac is freely available to all,{{cite web|url=http://copac.ac.uk/about|title=About Copac|first=Copac service|last=(Jisc)|website=copac.ac.uk}} and is widely used, with users mainly coming from [[Higher Education]] institutions in the [[United Kingdom]], but also worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://blog.copac.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/sites/12/2015/02/Copac-User-Survey-November-2014.pdf|author=Anon|year=2014|title=Copac User Survey|website=blog.copac.ac.uk}} Copac is valued by users as a research tool. Copac is searchable through with a [[web browser]] or [[Z39.50]] client. It is also accessible through [[OpenURL]] and [[Search/Retrieve via URL]] (SRU) interfaces.{{cite web|url=http://copac.ac.uk/developers|title=Copac for Developers|first=Copac service|last=(Jisc)|website=copac.ac.uk}} These interfaces can be used to provide links to items on Copac from external sites, such as those used on the [[Institute of Historical Research]] website.{{cite web|url=http://www.history.ac.uk/history-online/book/isbn/0195131010|title=Saints in Exile - History On-line|website=www.history.ac.uk}} Copac is a [[Jisc]] service provided for the UK community on the basis of an agreement with [[Research Libraries UK]] (RLUK).{{cite web|url=http://copac.ac.uk|title=Copac National, Academic and Specialist Library Catalogue|first=Copac service|last=(Jisc)|website=copac.ac.uk}} The service uses records supplied by RLUK members, as well as an increasing range of specialist libraries with collections of national research interest. A full list of contributors is available{{cite web|url=http://copac.ac.uk/about/libraries|title=Libraries on Copac|first=Copac service|last=(Jisc)|website=copac.ac.uk}} including the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty]], the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]], the [[Middle Temple]] library and [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] (IMechE) Library.{{cite journal|last1=Cousins|first1=Shirley|last2=Massam|first2=Diana|title=Copac developments and the Copac Collection Management service|journal=Interlending & Document Supply|volume=44|issue=1|year=2016|pages=17–19|issn=0264-1615|doi=10.1108/ILDS-11-2015-0036}} ==See also== * [[OPAC]] * [[SUNCAT]] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} [[Category:Academic libraries in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Bibliographic databases and indexes]] [[Category:Databases in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Higher education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:JISC]] [[Category:Library cataloging and classification]] [[Category:Online databases]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox Korean name | title = “Exemplar of Korean medicine” | hanja = 東醫寶鑑 | hangul = 동의보감 | rr = Dong(-)ui bogam | mr = Tongŭi pogam }} [[File:Dongibogam.jpg|thumb|TOC of ''Dongui Bogam'']]
The '''''Dongui Bogam''''' (동의보감) is a [[Korean language|Korean]] book compiled by the royal physician, [[Heo Jun]] (1539 – 1615) and was first published in 1613 during the [[Joseon Dynasty]] of [[Korea]]. The title literally means “a priceless book about medicines of an Eastern Country”. The word "Eastern" is not the antonym to the Western World's 'Western', but Heo Jun gave the book such a name because Eastern Country was one of the [[Names of Korea|sobriquets of Korea]]. The book is regarded as important in [[traditional Korean medicine]], and is one of the classics of Oriental medicine today. As of July 2009, it is on [[UNESCO]]’s [[Memory of the World Programme]].<ref>[http://www.korea.net/kois/eng_si_read.asp?slide_no=191 The History of Science in Korea] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222232827/http://www.korea.net/kois/eng_si_read.asp?slide_no=191 |date=December 22, 2008 }} Korean Culture and Information Service (KOIS)</ref> The original edition of Dongui Bogam is currently preserved by the Korean National Library.<ref name="db doosan">{{ko}} [http://100.naver.com/100.nhn?docid=50390 Dongui Bogam] at [[Doosan Encyclopedia]]</ref> The original was written in [[Hanja]] and only part of it was transcribed in Korean for wide reading use, as only officials understood in [[Hanja|Hanmun]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2011/04/142_49756.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409033523/https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2011/04/142_49756.html |archivedate=2015-04-09 |df= }}</ref> It was translated to English in 2013.<ref>https://kiom.re.kr/modedg/contentsView.do?ucont_id=CTX001017&menu_nix=jFB45u4H&srch_mu_lang=ENG</ref>
==Background== Known as one of the classics in the history of Eastern medicine, it was published and used in many countries including China and Japan, and remains a key reference work for the study of Eastern medicine. Its categorization and ordering of symptoms and remedies under the different human organs affected, rather than the disease itself, was a revolutionary development at that time. It contains insights that in some cases did not enter the medical knowledge of Europe until the twentieth century.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.koreanhero.net/fiftywonders/FiftyWonders2_English.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-09-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904181045/http://www.koreanhero.net/fiftywonders/FiftyWonders2_English.pdf |archive-date=2012-09-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Work on the ''Dongui Bogam'' started in the 29th year of [[Seonjo of Joseon|King Seonjo]]’s reign (1596) by the main physicians of ''Naeuiwon'' (내의원, “royal clinic”), with the objective to create a thorough compilation of traditional medicine. Main physician [[Heo Jun]] led the project but work was interrupted due to the [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592-1598)#Second invasion (1597–1598)|second Japanese invasion of Korea in 1597]]. King Seonjo did not see the project come to fruition, but Heo Jun steadfastedly stuck to the project and finally completed the work in 1610, the 2nd year of [[Gwanghaegun of Joseon|King Gwanghaegun]]’s reign.<ref name="db doosan"/><ref name="db kp">[http://www.koreanpress.net/news/view.asp?idx=3248&msection=9&ssection=54&page=1 An ancient medical text gains worldwide recognition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723173113/http://www.koreanpress.net/news/view.asp?idx=3248&msection=9&ssection=54&page=1 |date=July 23, 2011 }}, Korean Press</ref>
==The book== The ''Dongui Bogam'' consists of 25 volumes. In contrast to ''Hyangyak jipseongbang'' (향약집성방, "Compilation of Native Korean Prescriptions"), written in 1433, ''Dongui Bogam'' is more systematic. It not only refers to Korean medicinal texts, but also Chinese medicinal texts, and records illnesses practically with their respective remedies.<ref name="db ekc">{{ko}} [http://100.nate.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=K&i=236253&v=44 Dongui Bogam] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610014922/http://100.nate.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=K&i=236253&v=44 |date=June 10, 2011 }} at Encyclopedia of Korean Culture</ref>
===Contents=== The book is divided into 5 chapters: ''Naegyeongpyeon'' (내경편, 内景篇, Internal Medicine), ''Oehyeongpyeon'' (외형편, 外形篇, External Medicine), ''Japbyeongpyeon'' (잡병편, 難病編, Miscellaneous Diseases), ''Tangaekpyeon'' (탕액편, 湯液編, Remedies), and ''Chimgupyeon'' (침구편, 鍼灸編, Acupuncture).<ref name="db ekc"/><ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/flagship-project-activities/memory-of-the-world/register/full-list-of-registered-heritage/registered-heritage-page-2/donguibogam-principles-and-practice-of-eastern-medicine/], UNESCO</ref> *''Naegyeongpyeon'' primarily deals with physiologic functions and equivalent disorders of internal organs. The interactions of five organs - [[liver]], [[lungs]], [[kidneys]], [[heart]], and [[spleen]] - are thoroughly explained. *''Oehyeongpyeon'' explains the function of visible parts of the human body - skin, muscles, blood vessels, tendons, and bones - and the various related illnesses. *''Japbyeongpyeon'' deals with diagnosis and healing methods of various illnesses and disorders such as [[anxiety]], over-excitement, [[stroke]], cold, [[nausea]], [[edema]], [[jaundice]], [[Carbuncle|carbunculosis]], and others. This chapter also has a section for [[pediatrics]] and [[gynecology]]. *''Tangaekpyeon'' details methods for creating remedies and potions such as the collection of medicinal herbs and plants, creating and handling of medication, correct prescription and administration of medicine. All herbal medicine is categorized with explanations regarding their strength, gathering period and their common names for easy understanding. *''Chimgupyeon'' explains the acupuncture procedures for various ailments and disorders.
''Dongui Bogam'' offered not only medical facts, but also philosophical values of Eastern Asia. Heo Jun conveyed the message that maintaining the body’s energies in balance leads to one’s good health. The first page of the book is an anatomical map of the human body, linking human body with heaven and earth which embodies the Asian perspective of nature.<ref>{{ko}} [http://100.nate.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=B&i=128011&v=44 Dongui Bogam] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610015025/http://100.nate.com/dicsearch/pentry.html?s=B&i=128011&v=44 |date=June 10, 2011 }} at Britannica Korea</ref>
===Editions=== There have been several print editions of ''Dongui Bogam'' besides the original ''Naeuiwon'' edition, within Korea and abroad. The first Chinese edition was printed in 1763 with additional prints in 1796, and 1890. The Japanese edition was first printed in 1724, and then 1799.<ref name="db ekc"/>
==UNESCO Memory of the World Register and controversy== In 2009, UNESCO decided to add ''Dongui Bogam'' to the cultural heritage list due to its contribution as a historical relic and it was placed on [[UNESCO]]’s [[Memory of the World Programme]], becoming Korea's seventh cultural heritage to be thus included.<ref>[http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2009/07/148_49413.html Dongui Bogam] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130012157/http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2009/07/148_49413.html |date=January 30, 2010 }}, Korea Times, 2009-07-31.</ref> However, doctors clashed over ''Dongui Bogam'' after the official listing. The Korean Medical Association (KMA) downplayed the book’s importance saying that “it shouldn’t be taken as anything more than a recognition of the book’s value as a historical relic. It should not be taken as an acknowledgement of traditional medicine for its superior effectiveness” Listing the fact that the book is full of quackery such as how to bear a son or how to make yourself invisible. The KMA emphasized that ''Dongui Bogam'' was merely a cultural artifact and not science. The Association of Korean Oriental Medicine (AKOM) criticized the doctors of KMA for the lack of their appreciation of the influence of ''Dongui Bogam'' and history, saying it is necessary “to inherit and advance traditional medicine”.<ref>[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/tech/2010/01/133_49602.html Doctors Clash Over ‘Mirror of Eastern Medicine’] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409002954/https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/tech/2010/01/133_49602.html |date=April 9, 2015 }}, Korea Times, 2009-08-04.</ref>
==See also== * [[Heo Jun]] * [[Traditional Korean medicine]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Dongui Bogam}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090804195827/http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=27073&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html ''Donguibogam'': Principles and Practice of Eastern Medicine] at [[UNESCO]] website *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100618143901/http://www.dongui400.or.kr/ 400 years of ''Dongui Bogam''], Dongui Bogam Organization *[https://en.unesco.org/courier/novembre-2009/donguibogam-precious-book-korean-medicine ''Donguibogam, precious book of Korean medicine''], article published in the [[UNESCO Courier]]
[[Category:Korean non-fiction books]] [[Category:Medical books]] [[Category:Korean culture]] [[Category:Traditional Korean medicine]] [[Category:Memory of the World Register]] [[Category:1613 books]] [[Category:Ho Chun]] [[Category:National Treasures of South Korea]]

page.title: Eight or Nine Wise Words about Letter-Writing

revision.comment: italicize title and first mention, add italics, spelled out single-digit numerals, removed notability tag from 2014 (noted author, other notability per collectors)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Eight or Nine Wise Words about Letter-Writing''''' is an essay by [[Lewis Carroll]] on useful tips for composing, writing, mailing, and recording [[Letter (message)|letter]]s. The essay was published in 1890 by Emberlin and Son as a hardcover booklet consisting of 35 pages of text, followed by four pages of advertising, three pages of illustration, a stamp holder, and an illustration on the back cover.<ref>{{cite book|author=Carroll, Lewis|title=Eight or nine wise words on letter-writing|year=1890|publisher=Emberlin and Son|location=Oxford|url=https://archive.org/details/eightorninewisew00carr}}</ref> This essay is of some importance in [[philately]] because it was part of the [[Lewis Carroll#Inventions|"Wonderland" Postage-Stamp-Case]], which was first sold in 1889 by Emberlin and Son.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/wonderland-postage-stamp-case-invented-by-lewis-carroll-eight-or-nine-wise-words-about-letter-writing/oclc/559345006 The "Wonderland" Postage-Stamp-Case. Invented by Lewis Carroll. (''Eight or Nine Wise Words about Letter-Writing''), WorldCat.org]</ref><ref>[http://postalheritage.wordpress.com/2012/01/27/the-wonderland-postage-stamp-case/ The Wonderland Postage-Stamp Case, The British Postal Museum & Archive]</ref><ref>[http://www.liveauctioneers.com/item/6883057 Lot 26 - The Wonderland Postage-Stamp Case inscribed by Lewis Carroll, liveauctioneers.com]</ref> There were at least seven editions of the booklet and at least three editions of the stamp case.<ref>[http://catalog.loc.gov/vwebv/holdingsInfo?searchId=1148&recCount=25&recPointer=0&bibId=4145005 Library of Congress Online Catalog, ''Eight or nine wise words about letter-writing'', 1910]</ref>
==Table of Contents== *§1. On Stamp Cases *§2. How to Begin a Letter *§3. How to go on with a Letter *§4. How to end a Letter *§5. On registering Correspondence
==Nine Rules== Section 3 "How to go on with a Letter" contains nine rules for letter writing. *1st Rule. ''Write legibly''. *2nd Rule. Don't fill ''more'' than a page and a half with apologies for not having written sooner! The best subject, to ''begin'' with, is your friend's last letter. *3rd Rule. ''Don’t repeat yourself''. *4th Rule. When you have written a letter that you feel may possibly irritate your friend, however necessary you may have felt it to so express yourself, ''put it aside till the next day''. Then read it over again, and fancy it addressed to yourself. *5th Rule. If your friend makes a severe remark, either leave it unnoticed, or make your reply distinctly ''less'' severe: and if he makes a friendly remark, tending towards "making up" the little difference that has arisen between you, let your reply be distinctly ''more'' friendly. *6th Rule. ''Don’t try to have the last word''! *7th Rule. If it should ever occur to you to write, jestingly, in ''dispraise'' of your friend, be sure you exaggerate enough to make the jesting ''obvious'': a word spoken in ''jest'', but taken as earnest, may lead to very serious consequences. *8th Rule. When you say, in your letter, "I enclose cheque for £5," or "I enclose John’s letter for you to see," leave off writing for a moment—go and get the document referred to—and ''put it into the envelope''. Otherwise, you are pretty certain to find it lying about, ''after the Post has gone''! *9th Rule. When you get to the end of a notesheet, and find you have more to say, take another piece of paper—a whole sheet, or a scrap, as the case may demand: but whatever you do, ''don’t cross''! Remember the old proverb ''[[Crossed letter|Cross-writing]] makes cross reading''.
==See also== *[[Victorian letter writing guides]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gutenberg.org/38065/38065-h/38065-h.htm Online text at gutenberg.org]
{{Lewis Carroll}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Eight or Nine Wise Words about Letter-Writing}} [[Category:Works by Lewis Carroll]] [[Category:Letters (message)]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:Flora of australia.jpg|right|thumb|180px|The ''Flora of Australia'' Volume 1, second edition. All the book in the series have this distinctive green and yellow cover.]]
The '''''Flora of Australia''''' is a 59 volume series describing the vascular plants, bryophytes and lichens present in Australia and its external territories. The series is published by the [[Australian Biological Resources Study]] who estimate that the series when complete will describe over 20 000 plant species.<ref name = "Orchard" >Orchard, A. E. 1999. Introduction. In A. E. Orchard, ed. ''Flora of Australia - Volume 1'', 2nd edition pp 1-9. Australian Biological Resources Study {{ISBN|0-643-05965-2}}</ref>
==Series== Volume 1 of the series was published in 1981, a second extended edition was released in 1999. The series uses the [[Cronquist system]] of taxonomy. The ABRS also published the ''Fungi of Australia'', the ''Algae of Australia'' and the ''Flora of Australia Supplementary Series''. A new online ''Flora of Australia'' was launched by ABRS in 2017, and no more printed volumes will be published.<ref>{{cite web|title=Flora of Australia series|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/books/series/6|website=CSIRO Publishing|publisher=CSIRO Publishing|accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref>
==Other Australian floras== A few censuses of the Australian flora have been carried out, they include *1793-95 - [[James Edward Smith|J. E. Smith]] - ''Specimen of the Botany of New Holland'' *1804-05 - [[James Edward Smith|J. E. Smith]] - ''Exotic Botany'' *1804-07 - [[Jacques Labillardière|J. J. H. de Labillardière]] - ''Novae Hollandiae Plant. Spec'' *1810 - [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R. Brown]] - ''[[Prodromus Florae Novae Hollandiae et Insulae Van Diemen]]'' *1814 - [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R. Brown]] - ''Botanical Appendix to Flinders' Voyage'' *1849 - [[Robert Brown (botanist, born 1773)|R. Brown]] - ''Botanical Appendix to C. Sturt, Narrative of an Expedition into Central Australia'' *1856 - [[Joseph Dalton Hooker|J. D. Hooker]] - ''Introductory Essay, Flora Tasmaniae'' *1863-78 - [[George Bentham|G. Bentham]] - ''[[Flora Australiensis]]'' *1882 - [[Ferdinand von Mueller|F. Mueller]] - ''[[Systematic Census of Australian Plants]]'' *1889 - [[Ferdinand von Mueller|F. Mueller]] - ''Second Systematic Census'' *1990 - [[Roger Hnatiuk|R. J. Hnatiuk]] - ''Census of Australian Vascular Plants''
==See also== *[[Flora of Australia]] *[[Systematic Census of Australian Plants]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.deh.gov.au/biodiversity/abrs/online-resources/flora/main/index.html DEH.gov: Online ''Flora of Australia'' website] *[https://profiles.ala.org.au/opus/foa ''Flora of Australia'' online] {{Commonscat|position=left|Flora of Australia}}

2014–''present'' (as pro-government unit) |leaders= * Majid Himoud{{KIA}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/leader-prominent-pro-government-force-died-golan-heights/|title=Leader of prominent pro-government force has died in Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=18 June 2017|accessdate=22 June 2017}}{{sfnp|Inside Assad's Syria|2015}}{{Cite web|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/NewsReports/567236-pro-assad-militia-says-hit-by-israel|title=Pro-Assad militia says hit by Israel|work=NOW.|author=Albin Szakola|date=28 July 2016|accessdate=5 January 2017}} (chief commander until 2017) * Khaled Abaza{{cite web|url=https://www.almodon.com/arabworld/2017/12/22/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%B7%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D9%81%D9%88%D8%AC-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D9%88%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%88-%D8%B5%D9%82%D9%88%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%B7%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%B9-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D9%81%D9%88%D8%B0 |title="فوج الجولان" و"صقور القنيطرة" صراع خلفه "جمعية البستان"؟ |trans-title="The Golan Regiment" and "Hawks of Quneitra" conflict behind the "Bustan Society" |author= |work=Almodon |date=22 December 2017 |access-date=10 May 2018 }} (chief commander from 2017) |ideology= [[Anti-Zionism]]

offensive (June 2015)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/militant-offensive-in-al-quneitra-fails-to-yield-any-gains/|title=Militant Offensive in Al-Quneitra Fails to Yield Any Gains|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=18 June 2015|accessdate=5 January 2017}} * [[Quneitra offensive (October 2015)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-repels-the-islamist-rebels-at-tal-al-ahmar-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Syrian Army Repels the Islamist Rebels at Tal Al-Ahmar in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=4 October 2015|accessdate=5 January 2017}} * [[Ithriyah-Raqqa offensive (February–March 2016)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-enters-raqqa-liberating-zakiyah-crossroad-47-km-tabaqa-map/|title=Syrian Army enters Raqqa after liberating the Zakiyah Crossroad, 47 km to Tabaqa: map|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=11 February 2016|accessdate=5 January 2017}} * [[Palmyra offensive (March 2016)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/reinforcements-pour-palmyra-syrian-army-prepares-storm-city/|title=More reinforcements pour into Palmyra as the Syrian Army prepares to storm the city|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=22 March 2016|accessdate=6 January 2017}} * [[Ithriyah-Raqqa offensive (June 2016)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-advances-raqqa-border/|title=Developing: Syrian Army reaches the Raqqa border|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=2 June 2016|accessdate=8 January 2017}} * [[Quneitra offensive (September 2016)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/video-syrian-army-beats-back-jihadist-rebels-golan/|title=[Video] Syrian Army beats back the jihadist rebels in the Golan|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=29 July 2016|accessdate=5 January 2017}} * [[Palmyra offensive (December 2016)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-repels-first-isis-assault-t-4-airbase-prepares-second-wave/|title=Syrian Army repels first ISIS assault on T-4 Airbase, prepares for a second wave|author=Ivan Yakovlev|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=12 December 2016|accessdate=8 January 2017}} * [[Qaboun offensive (February–April 2017)]] * [[2017 Hama offensive]] * [[Palmyra offensive (2017)]]{{cite web|url=http://syrianobserver.com/EN/News/32921|title=Pro-Assad Militia Commander Killed in Quneitra Suicide Blast|work=The Syrian Observer|author=|date=21 June 2017|accessdate=22 June 2017}} * [[Eastern Homs offensive (2017)]] * [[Quneitra offensive (June 2017)]]{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-beats-back-jihadist-forces-golan-heights-despite-israeli-aggression/|title=Syrian Army beats back jihadist forces in Golan Heights despite Israeli aggression|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=25 June 2017|accessdate=26 June 2017}} *[[Battle of Harasta]]{{cite web | last=Waters | first=Gregory | title=The Growing Role of Reconciled Rebels in Syria | website=International Review | date=21 April 2018 | url=https://international-review.org/the-growing-role-of-reconciled-rebels-in-syria/ | access-date=30 October 2018}} * [[Beit Jinn offensive]] |active2=}} The '''Golan Regiment''' ([[Arabic]]: فوج الجولان, '''Fouj al-Joulan''') is a militia based in [[Khan Arnabah]] that is part of the [[National Defence Forces (Syria)|National Defence Forces]] (NDF). Though primarily active in the [[Golan Heights]], the unit has been deployed in various warzones of western Syria, fighting against many different [[Syrian opposition]] forces and the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]. The Golan Regiment is notable insofar as it was the first government unit during the [[Syrian Civil War]] that was founded by [[Free Syrian Army]] (FSA) defectors.{{sfnp|Inside Assad's Syria|2015}} == History == === Rebellion and return to the government side === [[File:Al-Mutasim Battalion formation.png|300px|left|thumb|The al-Mutasim Battalion announces its formation, declaring that it intends to defend the "great revolution" against the "corrupt" Assad government and its "thugs" and "mercenaries".]] The beginnings of the Golan Regiment trace back to 2011, when its later leader Majid Himoud volunteered for the [[Syrian Army]].{{sfnp|Inside Assad's Syria|2015}} According to Himoud, the officers in his division abused him and other soldiers, whereupon they decided to defect. In December 2011, they formed a [[Free Syrian Army]] unit under Himoud's leadership, the '''al-Mutasim Battalion''', and began to [[Early insurgency phase of the Syrian Civil War|fight against the government]] near the border to [[Israel]]. Allied with other local rebel groups, Himoud's men fought at Jabata, Khan Arnabah, [[Madinat al-Baath]], [[Beer Ajam]], and Breika, and [[Quneitra Governorate clashes (2012–14)|made good progress]] against the government. As time went on, however, Himoud became increasingly dissatisfied with his allies; he later claimed that some groups such as [[Alwiya al-Furqan]] "wouldn’t even fight, they would come to the battlefield after the clashes had ended, take pictures and videos next to destroyed buildings and tanks, and then send them back to their financiers in [[Jordan]] or the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Gulf states]] in order to collect their paychecks". Others he accused of closely working with [[Israel]], which he considered a "[[Red line (phrase)|red line]]" Syrians should not cross.{{efn|name=fn2|When asked about Himoud's claims, the [[Southern Front (Syrian rebel group)|Southern Front]] denied working with Israel, and said that "[Himoud] is an opportunist and a liar. He is a traitor and a regime agent."}} These factors led Himoud and many of his men reconsider their role as rebels, and in late 2013 he eventually contacted the mayor of Khan Arnabah, who was his relative and the NDF commander whose troops he was primarily fighting.{{sfnp|Inside Assad's Syria|2015}} The two agreed to a local ceasefire, and after eight months of negotiations, Himoud and dozens of his fighters handed themselves over to the government. They received an amnesty by president [[Bashar al-Assad]],{{sfnp|Inside Assad's Syria|2015}} and formed the "Golan Regiment" as National Defence Forces unit/[[Popular Committees (Syria)|Popular Committee]],{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-and-popular-committees-recapture-strategic-hilltop-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Syrian Army and Popular Committees Recapture Strategic Hilltop in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=13 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} centered in [[Khan Arnabah]]. The al-Mutasim Battalion members who disagreed with Himoud's decision and refused to defect instead joined other rebel groups. Since its foundation, the Golan Regiment has grown by recruiting government loyalists into its ranks, for example from [[Hader, Quneitra Governorate|Hader]],{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/free-syrian-army-and-the-syrian-armed-forces-agree-to-reconciliation-talks-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Free Syrian Army and the Syrian Armed Forces Agree to Reconciliation Talks in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=25 September 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} a mostly Druze town that is generally considered to be staunchly pro-Assad.{{cite web|url=http://www.joshualandis.com/blog/aymenn-jawad-al-tamimi-druze-militias-southern-syria/|title=Aymenn Jawad al-Tamimi: More On The Druze Militias in Southern Syria|publisher=Syria Comment|author=Aymenn Al-Tamimi |date=15 November 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} === As NDF unit === ==== Fighting in northern Quneitra 2015–16 ==== In course of the [[Quneitra offensive (June 2015)|Quneitra offensive]] in June 2015, the Golan Regiment and the Quneitra Hawks Brigade first held two strategic significant hills against numerous rebel assaults, and then aided the [[Syrian Army]] in retaking Tal Hamr and lifting the siege of Hader.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/breaking-syrian-army-recaptures-tal-hamr-in-al-quneitra-siege-of-hadar-lifted/|title=Breaking: Syrian Army Recaptures Tal Hamr in Al-Quneitra; Siege of Hadar Lifted|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=19 June 2015|accessdate=5 January 2017}} They consequently helped to fend off further attacks against Hader by the [[Southern Front (Syrian rebel group)|Southern Front]] and allied [[mujahideen]].{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/intense-firefights-erupt-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Intense Firefights Erupt in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=20 June 2015|accessdate=5 January 2017}} Throughout July, the Golan Regiment helped to defend several towns and hills in the Golan Heights against various Southern Front-led attacks,{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/southern-front-offensives-in-al-quneitra-daraa-and-al-sweida-has-been-forestalled/|title=Southern Front Offensives in Al-Quneitra, Dara’a and Al-Sweida has been Forestalled|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=5 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/southern-front-conducts-another-large-assault-on-the-golan-heights-and-daraa-city/|title=Southern Front Conducts Another Large Assault on the Golan Heights and Dara’a City|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=12 July 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-captures-tal-qabaa-near-the-israeli-bordder/|title=Syrian Army Captures Tal Qaba’a Near the Israeli Bordder|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=27 July 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} and participated in a major government counter-offensive in the area.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/new-al-quneitra-offensive-gets-off-to-a-fast-start/|title=New Al-Quneitra offensive gets off to a fast start|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=22 July 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} [[File:Rebel T-72 attacks Tal Kroum.png|300px|left|thumb|A [[Syrian opposition|rebel]] [[T-72]] shoots at the government positions on Tal Kroum, which were held by the Golan Regiment at the time.]] In September 2015, the regiment held reconciliation talks with [[Free Syrian Army]] (FSA) units that held Jabatha Al-Khasheb, [[Beit Jinn]], and Taranjah, though in the end the talks failed and fighting was resumed. As result, FSA and [[al-Nusra Front]] fighters launched another offensive to capture Hader and the surrounding countryside, with the Golan Regiment once again attempting to hold its positions at the frontline.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebels-rebuff-reconciliation-offer-and-launch-an-offensive-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Islamist Rebels Rebuff Reconciliation Offer and Launch an Offensive in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=27 September 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebels-launch-a-major-offensive-in-the-golan-with-the-help-of-israel/|title=Islamist Rebels Launch a Major Offensive in the Golan With the Help of Israel|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=29 September 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} On 2 October, the [[Islamism|Islamist]] [[Jaish al-Haramoun]] alliance and several FSA units launched [[Quneitra offensive (October 2015)|another offensive]] in Quneitra, first attacking Tall Ahmar, which was defended by the Golan Regiment and the Quneitra Hawks Brigade. After a fierce, two-days long battle, the hill fell into rebel hands and the NDF defenders were forced to withdraw.{{cite web|url=http://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebels-declare-control-of-tal-al-ahmar-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Islamist Rebels Declare Control of Tal Al-Ahmar in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=4 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} The Golan Regiment, along with other NDF and army units, launched a counter-attack to recapture Tall Ahmar on 7 October,{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-and-popular-committees-launch-counter-attack-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Syrian Army and Popular Committees Launch Counter-Attack in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=7 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} which was repelled. Opposition troops then also took control of the nearby "UN hill",{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebels-declare-control-over-u-n-hill-in-al-quneitra-renewed-offensive-at-tal-qabaa/|title=Islamist Rebels Declare Control Over U.N. Hill in Al-Quneitra; Renewed Offensive at Tal Qaba’a|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=10 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} though NDF forces, including the Golan Regiment, reversed this rebel gain a few hours later.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-reverses-islamist-gains-in-the-golan-u-n-hill-recaptured/|title=Syrian Army Reverses Islamist Gains in the Golan: U.N. Hill Recaptured|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=11 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} In course of the next weeks, the Golan Regiment helped to recapture all positions taken by rebel forces during the offensive.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-captures-the-4th-battalion-base-in-the-golan-heights/|title=Syrian Army Captures the 4th Battalion Base in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=24 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} In late December 2015, the Golan Regiment participated in a government attack on West Al-Samdaniyah, which was captured after hard fighting; soon after its capture, however, the army retreated from the town for unknown reasons, so that it was retaken by rebels.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-withdraws-from-west-al-samdaniyah/|title=Syrian Army withdraws from West Al-Samdaniyah|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=24 October 2015|accessdate=6 January 2017}} The regiment and other government units once again held reconciliation talks with local FSA rebels in the following January.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/reconciliation-talks-begin-in-thr-golan-heights/|title=Reconciliation talks begin in the Golan Heights|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=6 January 2016|accessdate=6 January 2017}} Later that month, the [[9th Armoured Division (Syria)|9th Armoured Division]]'s 90th Brigade and the Golan Regiment successfully ambushed an al-Nusra Front and [[Ahrar al-Sham]] convoy near the [[Shebaa farms]].{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamist-rebels-ambushed-on-the-way-to-the-lebanese-shebaa-farms/|title=Islamist rebels ambushed on the way to the Shebaa Farms|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=21 January 2016|accessdate=6 January 2017}} On 29 January, the Golan Regiment helped to repel renewed rebel attacks against the contested hill of Tal Kroum.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/islamists-launch-new-offensive-in-southwestern-syria/|title=Islamists launch new offensive in southwestern Syria|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=30 January 2016|accessdate=6 January 2017}} ==== Expanded operations 2016–17 ==== Beginning with February 2016, when the unit sent its fighters north to participate in the [[Ithriyah-Raqqa offensive (February–March 2016)|first government offensive]] to retake ISIL-held Al-Tabqa Military Airport, the Golan Regiment became far more active outside of Quneitra Governorate. Though the aforementioned offensive eventually stalled and was discontinued, the Golan Regiment also aided the [[Palmyra offensive (March 2016)|recapture]] of [[Palmyra]] from ISIL in March. Later in June, its militiamen were once again involved in [[Ithriyah-Raqqa offensive (June 2016)|another attempt]] by the government to regain Al-Tabqa Military Airport; which ended in a complete defeat as the pro-government forces were routed by ISIL counter-attacks. Meanwhile, the Golan Regiment continued its defence of the Hader area. On 6 June the [[Criterion Brigades]] launched an offensive called "At Your Service Darayya" in order to draw government forces from the [[Siege of Darayya and Muadamiyat]] to reinforce the front in [[Quneitra]]. The Brigades allegedly seized 2 villages, which was promptly denied by the Golan Regiment.{{cite web|url= https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/NewsReports/567071-quneitra-rebels-aim-to-relieve-siege-of-darayya|title=Quneitra rebels aim to relieve siege of Darayya|work=NOW.|author=Albin Szakola|date=7 June 2016|accessdate=6 January 2017}} On 28 July, the [[Israel Defense Forces]] attacked the Golan Regiment, launching missiles at the convoy of Majid Himoud and two mortar emplacements of the unit at [[Madinat al-Baath]]. While Himoud survived, the militia denounced Israel for its "[[Zionism|Zionist]]" attacks.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/israeli-drone-strikes-target-the-national-defense-forces-and-the-pflp-gc/|title=Israeli Drone Strikes Target the National Defense Forces and the PFLP-GC|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=29 July 2016|accessdate=5 January 2017}} {{quote box | width = 35em | align = right |quoted = yes | quote = We are good at what we do and the army relies on us to stop the opposition from penetrating the front lines in Quneitra, precisely because some of our groups used to be with the opposition groups. Majid [Himoud] and the others know who they are personally, know how they think and how they fight. This helps our fight against them. | salign = right | source = Mohammad Zeidan, Golan Regiment fighter since 2014. }} The following September saw a resurgence in the fighting for the Golan Heights, as Jihadist-led rebels launched a [[Quneitra offensive (September 2016)|large-scale offensive]] in the area, with the Golan Regiment once again at the forefront in the defense of Hader. Throughout the battle, the Golan Regiment accused Israel of supporting the Islamist rebels,{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/israeli-army-returns-14-bodies-jihadist-rebels-golan-heights-offensive/|title=Israeli Army returns 14 bodies to the jihadist rebels after Golan Heights offensive|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[al-Masdar News]]|date=14 June 2016|accessdate=8 January 2017}} and on 17 September, the unit once again became the target of an [[Israeli Air Force]] (IAF) strike that killed one and wounded 5 of its militiamen. The strike was in retaliation for a stray mortar shell that had hit Israeli territory.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/israeli-air-force-attacks-syrian-army-golan-heights/|title=Israeli Air Force attacks Syrian Army in the Golan Heights|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|author=Leith Fadel|date=17 September 2016|accessdate=5 January 2017}} On the other side, the pro-opposition Al-Etihad accused the Golan Regiment of having disguised [[Hezbollah]] fighters in its ranks.{{cite web|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/NewsReports/567345-hezbollah-secretly-deploying-in-quneitra-report|title=Hezbollah "secretly" deploying in Quneitra: report|work=NOW.|author=Albin Szakola|date=9 September 2016|accessdate=6 January 2017}} While the rebel offensive was eventually repelled, a later government counter-offensive supported by the Golan Regiment equally yielded no gains.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-launches-surprise-offensive-golan-heights/|title=Syrian Army launches surprise offensive in Golan Heights|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|author=Leith Fadel|date=26 September 2016|accessdate=8 January 2017}} Meanwhile, after the [[Syrian Revolutionaries Front]] (SRF)'s branch in [[Jubata al-Khashab]] collapsed amid internal discord, the local SRF commander defected to the Golan Regiment.{{cite web|url=http://www.rubincenter.org/2017/07/israels-relations-with-the-syrian-rebels-an-assessment/|title=Arab Media: Israeli Bombardment Killed, Wounded Targets inside Syria|author=[[Aymenn Jawad Al-Tamimi]]|editor=[[Jonathan Spyer]]|publisher=Rubin Center|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=4 July 2017}} The unit spearheaded a government attack in November 2016 that secured the northern part of a strategic highway in the Golan Heights.{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/latest-battlefield-map-golan-heights/|title=Latest battlefield map of the Golan Heights|work=[[Al-Masdar News]]|author=Leith Fadel|date=24 November 2016|accessdate=8 January 2017}} In December, the Golan Regiment sent reinforcements to the [[Tiyas Military Airbase]] in an attempt to halt a [[Palmyra offensive (December 2016)|massive ISIL offensive]] in the region. On 17 and 26 January 2017, the regiment reportedly helped to repel two rebel attacks in the areas around Hader.{{cite web|url=http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13951028000502|title=Syria in Last 24 Hours: Army Wins Back More Strategic Regions Near Ancient Palmyra|author=|publisher=[[Fars News Agency]]|date=17 January 2017|accessdate=13 February 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://en.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13951107000693|title=Quneitra: Al-Nusra Front's Base Destroyed, Terrorists' Offensive Repulsed|work=[[Fars News Agency]]|author=|date=26 January 2017|accessdate=28 January 2017}} On 19 March, the Israeli Air Force targeted the Golan Regiment commander Yasser Hussein al-Sayyed{{efn|name=fn1}} with a [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]] as he was travelling to [[Damascus]] by car. Both he as well as his driver were killed. The attack was seen as Israeli retaliation for the attempt of the [[Syrian Air Defense Force]] to shoot down an IAF jet that had bombarded Hezbollah positions near Palmyra. Meanwhile, the unit also helped countering rebel offensives in [[Qaboun offensive (February–April 2017)#Rebel attack from Jobar|Jobar]] and [[2017 Hama offensive|northern Hama]], and took part in the operations in the [[Syrian Desert]] in course of which the government again [[Palmyra offensive (2017)|retook Palmyra]] and [[Eastern Homs offensive (2017)|pushed back]] ISIL in eastern [[Homs Governorate]]. On 16 June, a suicide bomber struck Majid Himoud as he was meeting with other Golan Regiment fighters in Khan Arnabah; two members of the unit were killed instantly, while Himoud was wounded and brought to a hospital. There he succumbed to his wounds two days later. He was replaced by Khaled Abaza as chief commander of the militia, while Yassin Salibi became the new head of the Golan Regiment's First Battalion. Later that month, the Golan Regiment aided the Syrian Army and other pro-government militias in repelling a major [[Quneitra offensive (June 2017)|rebel offensive]] against [[Madinat al-Baath]]; in course of the fighting, the unit was once again bombed by the Israeli Air Force.{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/middle-east/syria/arab-media-israeli-bombardment-killed-wounded-targets-inside-syria/2017/06/26/|title=Arab Media: Israeli Bombardment Killed, Wounded Targets inside Syria|author=Leith Fadel|publisher=[[The Jewish Press]]|date=26 June 2017|accessdate=26 June 2017}} The Golan Regiment helped to repel an [[Tahrir al-Sham]]-led attack on Hader in September 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/jihadists-launch-new-offensive-golan-heights/|title=Jihadists launch new offensive in Golan Heights |author=Leith Fadel |work=[[al-Masdar News]] |date=8 September 2017 |access-date=9 September 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-allies-fully-reverse-al-qaeda-offensive-golan-heights/|title=Syrian Army, allies fully reverse Al-Qaeda offensive in Golan Heights |author=Andrew Illingworth |work=[[al-Masdar News]] |date=8 September 2017 |access-date=9 September 2017}} In late 2017, the Golan Regiment relocated much of its forces from other regions of Syria to the Golan Heights in response to rumors about another rebel offensive.{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-readies-forces-golan-heights-amid-jihadist-build-israeli-threats/ |title=Syrian Army readies its forces in the Golan Heights amid jihadist build-up, Israeli threats |author=Leith Fadel |work=[[al-Masdar News]] |date=17 August 2017 |access-date=12 October 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-army-storms-last-jihadist-bastion-near-occupied-golan-heights/ |title=Syrian Army storms last jihadist bastion near occupied Golan Heights |author=Leith Fadel |work=[[al-Masdar News]] |date=29 November 2017 |access-date=23 March 2018}} Meanwhile, disputes erupted among the Golan Regiment's leadership. After becoming the new leader of the militia, Khaled Abaza had grown increasingly powerful, having been appointed as head of [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region|Ba'ath Party]]'s branch in Quneitra Governorate and effectively taking control of Khan Arnabah. He eventually tried to oust Yassin Salibi as leader of the First Battalion, but Yassin found the support of the Quneitra Hawks Brigade and the [[al-Bustan Association]] of pro-government businessman [[Rami Makhlouf]], both of which were wary of Kaled's power. In consequence, the Golan Regiment's Fist Battalion and the Quneitra Hawks Brigade forces in Khan Arnabah, supported by the al-Bustan Association, merged to form the "National Shield of the Patriotic Forces" in December 2017. This new formation was about 1,500 strong and to be led by Mohammed al-Hajj. This development reduced Khaled's control to the Golan Regiment's Second and Third Battalion. The "National Shield" then took part in the [[Beit Jinn offensive]]. In March 2018, the Golan Regiment and the Quneitra Hawks Brigade occupied Point 99, a hill west of [[Beit Jinn]], as result of the agreement between the government and rebel forces following the Beit Jinn offensive's conclusion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/pictures-syrian-forces-impose-control-over-strategic-height-near-israeli-occupied-golan-amid-preparations-for-new-offensive/ |title=Pictures: Syrian forces impose control over strategic height near Israeli-occupied Golan amid preparations for new offensive |author=Andrew Illingworth |work=[[al-Masdar News]] |date=16 March 2018 |access-date=23 March 2018}} Artillery fire again struck Israeli territory during renwed clashes in Quneitra Governorate in July 2018, whereupon the Israeli military responded by bombarding areas in Al-A'ayyaz near Khan Arnabah that were controlled by the Golan Regiment.{{cite web|url=https://www.almodon.com/arabworld/2018/7/7/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%B7%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%A9-%D9%81%D8%A7%D8%B4%D9%84%D8%A9-%D9%84%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B6%D8%A9-%D9%88%D8%A5%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%8A%D9%84-%D8%AA%D8%B1%D8%AF-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86 |title=القنيطرة:معركة فاشلة للمعارضة..وإسرائيل ترد على مصادر النيران |trans-title=Quneitra: A failed battle for the opposition. Israel responds to the sources of fire |author= |work=Almodon |date=7 July 2018 |access-date=17 July 2018 }} == Organization == The Golan Regiment is split into three parts: The "First Battalion" of Khan Arnabah, the "Second Battalion" of [[Hader, Quneitra Governorate|Hader]], and the "Third Battalion" of [[Jaba, Syria|Jaba]]. The founder of the militia, Majid Himoud, served as both chief commander and leader of the First Battalion before his death in June 2017. Thereafter, the militia's overall leader was Khaled Abaza, a [[Circassians in Syria|Circassian]] from [[Beer Ajam]] and the son of [[Brigadier]] Walid Abaza who served as head of the [[Political Security Directorate]]'s branch in [[Hama]] during the [[Islamist uprising in Syria]]. By late 2017, the battalions were led by Yassin Salibi (First), Abu Mashhour (Second), and Abu Suhaib (Third). Another notable officer in the Golan Regiment was Yasser Hussein al-Sayyed.{{efn|name=fn1|Al-Sayyed's position within the regiment is disputed. He has been described as commander by news agencies,{{Cite web|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/03/israel-carries-out-two-strikes-against-assad-regime-hezbollah-targets-in-syria.php|title=Israel Carries Out Two Strikes Against Assad Regime, Hezbollah Targets in Syria|work=Long War Journal|author=David Daoud|date=21 March 2017|accessdate=22 March 2017}} while the unit's leadership insists that he was "a fighter with no particular rank".}} ==See also== {{Portal|Syria|Palestine|Syrian Civil War}} *[[List of armed groups in the Syrian Civil War]] == Notes == {{notelist}} == References == {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{Cite episode | title = Inside Assad's Syria | episode-link = | url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/film/inside-assads-syria/ | access-date = | series = Frontline | series-link = Frontline (U.S. TV series) | first1 = Martin | last1 = Smith |authorlink1= Martin Smith (documentarian) | first2 = Linda | last2 = Hirsch | network = [[PBS]] | station = | date = 27 October 2015 | season = 33 | number = 18 | minutes = | time = | transcript = Transcript | transcript-url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/foreign-affairs-defense/inside-assads-syria/transcript-91/ | quote = | language = English |ref = {{harvid|Inside Assad's Syria|2015}} }} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9toO1pUVnnI Daraa governate 18/12/2011. Defectors form Al-Mu'tasim Battalion of the Free Syrian Army]. [[Ugarit News]], 18 December 2011 {{Syrian Civil War}} [[Category:2011 establishments in Syria]] [[Category:Anti-government factions of the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Anti-ISIL factions in Syria]] [[Category:Ba'athist organizations]] [[Category:Druze]] [[Category:Pro-government factions of the Syrian Civil War]]

revision.comment: /* Court rulings */ Either "Justices Black and Douglas" or "Justice Black and Justice Douglass". I chose the latter.
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Goldwater v. Ginzburg''''' was a 1969 United States court ruling on [[defamation]].<ref name=tele/>
==Background== [[Fact (U.S. magazine)|''Fact'' Magazine]] (''Fact'') was a corporation in New York. The defendant, [[Ralph Ginzburg]], was the editor and publisher of ''Fact'', and [[Warren Boroson]], a co-defendant in this case, was the managing editor of ''Fact''. The plaintiff, [[Barry Goldwater]], was a United States Senator from Arizona and had been [[Barry Goldwater presidential campaign, 1964|a 1964 presidential candidate]]. The defendants testified that they attended the July 1964 Republican National Convention and were not impressed with Senator Goldwater. Thus, they decided to warn the American people in an issue of their magazine (soon known as the "Goldwater issue"<ref name="leagle">[http://www.leagle.com/decision/1969738414F2d324_1661.xml/GOLDWATER%20v.%20GINZBURG Goldwater v. Ginzburg 414 F.2d 324 (1969)]</ref> of ''Fact'') immediately after Goldwater's nomination on July 16th.
The issue at hand was the article published by ''Fact'' titled "The Unconscious of a Conservative: A Special Issue on the Mind of Barry Goldwater" in the September-October 1964 issue. The magazine polled [[psychiatrists]] and asked if Goldwater was psychologically fit to serve as president.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=LBJ Fit to Serve |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=D24hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F4cFAAAAIBAJ&pg=882,4721408&dq=ralph+ginzburg&hl=en |quote=Publisher Ralph Ginzburg, defendant in a libel suit for an article on a poll of psychiatrists on Barry Goldwater that he conducted in 1964 says ... |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |date=May 23, 1968 |accessdate=2011-05-24 }}</ref> ''Fact'' used the information given from the polls in the magazine article against Senator Goldwater. Senator Goldwater sued ''Fact'' Magazine, Inc., Ginzburg, and Boroson for "false, scandalous and defamatory statements referring to and concerning [the] plaintiff.” <ref name="leagle" />
==Court rulings== The court found that the evidence introduced at trial proved the defendants knew they were publishing defamatory statements and “were motivated by actual malice when they published the statements.”<ref name="leagle" /> The court found the defendants guilty of libel action based on the article ''Fact'' published. The plaintiff demanded $1,000,000 in compensatory and punitive damages but Senator Goldwater was awarded $1 in compensatory damages and $75,000 in punitive damages. The compensatory damages were against all defendants but the punitive damages were split between the defendants. Ginzburg and Boroson were liable for $25,000 of the $75,000 and ''Fact'' Magazine, Inc. was liable for $50,000. The United States Court of Appeals affirmed the award and the Supreme Court denied a petition for ''certiorari'' (review); [[Hugo Black|Justice Black]] and [[William O. Douglas|Justice Douglas]] joined a dissenting opinion, rather unusual at the time (1970) on orders denying “cert.”<ref>414 F.2d 324, 337 (2d Cir.1969), cert. denied, 396 US 1049, 90 S.Ct. 701, 24 L.Ed.2d 695.</ref> Boroson was the only defendant not to file an appeal after receiving the ruling.
==Commentary== Although over 1,800 psychiatrists responded to the polls sent by Ginzburg, the medical director{{ambiguous|date=August 2017}} at the time, Walter Barton, sent a protest warning Ginzburg that "a psychiatrist’s evaluation must take place in the context of a doctor-patient relationship and a “thorough clinical examination"."<ref name="psychiatryonline">[http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/doi/full/10.1176/appi.ajp.2015.14111410 "Goldwater v. Ginzburg." American Journal of Psychiatry, 172(8), pp. 729–730]</ref> The [[American Psychiatric Association]] then issued the [[Goldwater rule]] reaffirming [[medical privacy]] and forbidding commenting on a patient that any individual psychiatrist has not personally examined.<ref name=tele>{{cite news |author=[[Richard A. Friedman]] |coauthors= |title=How a Telescopic Lens Muddles Psychiatric Insights |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/24/health/views/24mind.html?ref=science |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=May 23, 2011 |accessdate=2011-05-24 }}</ref>

{{Infobox library |name=Interference Archive |image=Interference Archive poster.jpg |country=United States |type=[[Archive]] |established=2011 |location=[[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |coordinates={{coord|40.672487|-73.991402|display=inline,title|dim:20000_region:US-NY_type:edu}} |website=http://interferencearchive.org/ }} '''Interference Archive''' is a volunteer-run [[library]], [[art gallery|gallery]], and [[archive]] of [[historical document|historical materials]] related to [[social activism|social]] and [[political activism]] and [[social movement|movements]]. It is located in the [[Park Slope]] neighborhood of [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]].
==History==
Interference Archive began as the personal collection of [[Josh MacPhee]] and [[Dara Greenwald]], [[activist]]s who told the ''[[New York Times]]'' that they had filled their home with so much "social movement memorabilia ... Ph.D. students would visit to conduct research."<ref name=nyt/><ref name=ifla/><ref name=reframe/> The idea to turn it into a public resource began in 2008 when the couple was asked to curate an exhibition at the [[Exit Art]] gallery in [[Manhattan]]. Using the title "Signs of Change," it showcased cultural artifacts produced by those engaged with groups organizing to foment change.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=rail/><ref name=signsflickr/> The show and research they did in preparation for it is reflected in the Interference Archive mission statement which begins, "Interference Archive explores the relationship between cultural production and social movements."<ref name=mission/> MacPhee and Greenwald also point to archives and libraries of similar scope and purpose as inspiration, including another Brooklyn-based organization, the [[Lesbian Herstory Archives]].<ref name=juice/>
In 2010 MacPhee and Greenwald moved their collection to a warehouse in [[Gowanus]], in collaboration with activists and artists Molly Fair and Kevin Caplicki. Greenwald named it Interference Archive, referring to "the idea that the collection causes static, or interference, in institutional archives and in the larger society."<ref name=rail/><ref name=juice/><ref name=obscura/> It opened its doors to the public in December 2011 with a [[punk subculture|punk]] and [[feminism]] themed exhibition in tribute to Greenwald, who had been struggling with [[endometrial cancer]] and died the following month.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=rail/> [[File:Interference Archive.jpg|thumb|Exterior of the Interference Archive's location in [[Park Slope, Brooklyn]]]]
The rising prominence and popularity of the [[Occupy movement]] emerged as one specific motivation around the time of the Archive's opening, when its founders observed among Occupy participants a need for information about social movements of the past.<ref name=guardian/><ref name=aiga/>
Interference Archive has broadened its activities significantly since opening, operating as a library and community space and hosting regular talks, art exhibitions, performances, workshops, and other events.
''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s Edward Helmore, assessing the place of the Archive among other arts institutions, described it as "far removed from the realm of commercial art galleries, oligarch collectors, the show-palace museums of billionaire real estate developers, and under the watch of gun-toting revolutionaries from several decades back — and is far the richer for it."<ref name=guardian/>
{{as of|2014}} it operates on a yearly budget of less than $25,000, supported primarily by donations from a community of financial sustainers.<ref name=nyt/>
In October 2017, after being evicted from their space in Gowanus, the archive relocated to the nearby [[Park Slope, Brooklyn|Park Slope]] neighborhood of Brooklyn and reopened to the public in December 2017.<ref name=aiga/> The inaugural exhibit in the new space entitled ''no. NOT EVER'' opened in January 2018. The exhibit is a multidisciplinary and video-based exploration of "the rise of white nationalism" in America.<ref>{{cite web|title=no. NOT EVER. at Interference Archive|url=http://interferencearchive.org/no-not-ever/|website=Interference Archive Events|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>
==Collection==
The archive is housed in an open floor-plan storefront space, filled to the ceiling.<ref name=nyt/> The collection includes a number of different kinds of media artifacts which provide information and illustration about the histories of radical political movements around the world, with 40% of the archive coming from outside the [[United States]].<ref name=juice/> Among the materials are [[poster]]s, [[flyer (pamphlet)|fliers]], [[pamphlet]]s, [[zine]]s, [[sticker]]s, [[T-shirt]]s, [[book]]s, [[graphic novel]]s, [[newspaper]]s, [[game]]s, [[video]]s, [[leaflet (information)|leaflets]], [[Button (clothing)|button]]s, [[audio recording]]s, and other [[ephemera]].<ref name=nyt/><ref name=rail/><ref name=mission/> The topics it covers includes [[ACT-UP]], [[Occupy Wall Street]], [[Arab Spring]], [[Code Pink]], [[Pink Bloque]], [[Rock for Choice]], [[Latin American art]], [[nature]], [[ecology]], [[feminism]], [[punk rock]], [[criminal justice]], [[prison reform]], [[apartheid]], [[anti-nuclear movement]], [[squatting]], [[Anarchist Bookfair|anarchist bookfairs]], [[May 1968 events in France]], and [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[anti-fur]] activism.<ref name=rail/><ref name=juice/><ref name=blouin/>
MacPhee summarizes the conceptual basis for the collection as "material produced by people organizing to transform the world".<ref name=guardian/>
The owners and volunteers take a pointedly nontraditional approach to [[archivism]]. In selection and acquisition, no priority is given to particular movements, media types, or well-known artists.<ref name=rail/> Instead, it positions itself as a [[commons]] where people can share what they have and benefit from what was donated by others.<ref name=rail/><ref name=juice/> Whereas most archives stress materials protection and preservation, the Interference Archive promotes access, physical engagement, and use of the materials to maintain their continued relevance outside of the Archive.<ref name=rail/><ref name=aiga/> Collections are also organized for usability, prioritizing media type and subject over donation or donor.<ref name=aiga/>
==Events and activities== [[File:Interference Archive Persistence of Dreams November 2012.jpg|thumb|right|La Persistencia de los Sueños / The Persistence of Dreams event, a retrospective of the work of Mexican graphics collective Sublevarte in November 2012]]
In addition to its primary purpose as an archive and library, Interference Archive also functions as a multipurpose community center, gallery, and events space.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=rail/> Past events and exhibitions have covered prison reform,<ref name=dailynews/><ref name=hyperallergic/> the [[Asian American movement]] in New York,<ref name=scmp/><ref name=manifesto/> underground newspapers,<ref name=kommersant/> the anti-nuclear movement,<ref name=nycarchivists/> and [[Art+Feminism]] [[edit-a-thon]]s.<ref name=newyorkerlavin/>
''Armed by Design'', a 2015 exhibition, comprised graphic art from ''[[Tricontinental]]'', a magazine published by the Cuba-based [[anti-globalization]], [[anti-imperialist]], [[anticapitalist]] organization OSPAAL ([[Organization of Solidarity with the People of Asia, Africa and Latin America]]). ''[[The Guardian]]'' described it as "a fascinating tour of 60s and 70s radical politics and its heroes".<ref name=guardian/>
In addition to historical materials and preexisting cultural products, the Archive occasionally commissions artists to produce original work. For ''Armed by Design'', the 60s and 70s graphics were supplemented by a new set of topical posters.<ref name=guardian/> Another exhibit, ''if a song could be freedom... Organized Sounds of Resistance'', included a series of annotated mixtapes compiled by musicians, historians, and activists.<ref name=guardian/>
One exhibit in April 2013 featured "book blocs", home-made [[cardboard]] [[shield]]s glued together by activists for use during [[college tuition]] protests.<ref name=newyorkerbarliant/> The shields on display as well as others made during a workshop earlier in the month were confiscated as weapons by the [[New York Police Department]] the day before they were due to be used at [[Cooper Union]] in a protest against the school's decision to begin charging tuition.<ref name=newyorkerbarliant/><ref name=6thfloor/>
Since 2015, volunteers have hosted a [[podcast]] which highlights material in the collections and associated exhibits.<ref name=aiga/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox museum | name = The J. Paul Getty Museum | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Aerial_Getty_Museum.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{Coord|34|04|39|N|118|28|30|W|source:itwiki_region:US-CA_type:landmark|display=inline, title}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|1974|df=y}} <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = 1200 Getty Center Drive, [[Los Angeles, California]]; and 17985 Pacific Coast Highway, [[Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles, California]] | type = [[Art museum]] | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = 2,023,467 (2016)<ref name="visitors">{{cite web |url=https://www.museus.gov.br/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/20170406-CPAI-Ranking2016Pub-Comp-.pdf |title=Visitor Figures 2016 |page=14 |publisher=[[The Art Newspaper]] Review |date=April 2017 |accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref> | founder = | director = [[Timothy Potts]] | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{url|www.getty.edu/museum/}} | embedded = }}
The '''J. Paul Getty Museum''', commonly referred to as '''the Getty''', is an [[art museum]] in [[California]] housed on two campuses: the [[Getty Center]] and [[Getty Villa]]. The two locations received over two million visitors in 2016.<ref name=visitors/>
The primary museum, the Getty Center, is located in [[Brentwood, Los Angeles, California|Brentwood]] neighborhood of [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], on a hill top above the west side of the [[Sepulveda Pass]] and [[Interstate 405 (California)|I-405]] freeway. Its collection features Western art from the [[Middle Ages]] to the present.
The secondary museum, the Getty Villa, is in the Malibu neighborhood and displays art from [[Ancient Greece]], [[Rome]], and [[Etruria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://getty.edu/visit/ |title=Visit the Getty |publisher=Getty.edu |date= |accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref>
== History ==
In 1974, [[J. Paul Getty]] opened a museum in a re-creation of the [[Villa of the Papyri]] at [[Herculaneum]] on his property in [[Malibu, California]].<ref>{{cite web|title=THE GETTY VILLA TO OPEN JANUARY 28, 2006|url=http://www.getty.edu/news/press/center/villa_ticketing_release.html|work=Press Release|publisher=J. Paul Getty Trust|accessdate=June 16, 2012}}</ref> In 1982, the museum became the richest in the world when it inherited US$1.2 billion.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE0DD133DF937A35750C0A961948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all | work=The New York Times | title=Getty, The Art World's Big Spender | first=Douglas C. | last=McGill | date=March 4, 1987 | accessdate=May 5, 2010}}</ref> In 1983, after an economic downturn in what was then [[West Germany]], the Getty Museum acquired 144 [[Illuminated manuscript|illuminated medieval manuscripts]] from the financially struggling Ludwig Collection in Aachen; [[John Russell (art critic)|John Russell]], writing in ''[[The New York Times]]'', said of the collection, "One of the finest holdings of its kind ever assembled, it is quite certainly the most important that was in private hands."<ref>Eric Pace (July 23, 1996), [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/23/arts/peter-ludwig-71-german-art-collector-dies.html Peter Ludwig, 71, German Art Collector, Dies] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> In 1997, the museum moved to its current location in the [[Brentwood, Los Angeles, California|Brentwood]] neighborhood of Los Angeles; the Malibu museum, renamed the "[[Getty Villa]]", was renovated and reopened in 2006.
== GettyGuide == {{brochure|date=October 2018}} [[File:J. Paul Getty Museum 2015.jpg|thumb|left|The Getty attracts approximately 1.8 million visitors a year.<ref>{{cite web|title=The J. Paul Getty Trust|url=http://www.getty.edu/about/trust.html|website=The Getty|publisher=J. Paul Getty Museum|accessdate=May 19, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526082307/http://www.getty.edu/about/trust.html|archivedate=May 26, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>]] Detailed information about the J. Paul Getty Museum’s collections is provided on GettyGuide, a suite of interactive multimedia tools available at the Museum, as well as on getty.edu. At the GettyGuide stations in the Museum, visitors can get information about exhibitions, interact with a timeline, watch videos on art-making techniques, and more. Also available at the Museum, the GettyGuide multimedia player features commentary from curators and conservators on many works of art. With GettyGuide on the Web, one may browse the Museum’s collection<ref>{{cite web | title = Collection (Getty Museum) | publisher = J. Paul Getty Museum | url = http://www.getty.edu/art/}}</ref> and bookmark works of art to create a customized tour and printable map.<ref>{{cite web | title = Getty Bookmarks | publisher = J. Paul Getty Museum | url = http://www.getty.edu/mygetty/ | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110806061140/https://www.getty.edu/mygetty/ | archivedate = August 6, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> [[File:J. Paul Getty Museum courtyard.jpg|thumb|Architect [[Richard Meier]] chose beige-colored Italian [[travertine]] panels to cover the retaining walls and to serve as paving stones for the arrival plaza and Museum courtyard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getty.edu/visit/center/architecture.html|title=The Getty Center - Architecture|website=The Getty|publisher=J. Paul Getty Museum|accessdate=May 21, 2015}}</ref>]]
== The controversies with Italy and Greece == In the 1970s and 1980s, the curator, [[Jiří Frel]], designed a tax manipulation scheme which expanded the museum collection of antiquities, essentially buying artifacts of dubious provenance, as well as a number of artifacts generally considered fakes, such as the [[Getty kouros]]. In 1984, Frel was demoted, and in 1986, he resigned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/may/13/local/me-frel13|title=Jiri Frel, 82; Colorful Curator Who Left Getty Under a Cloud|last=Frammolino|first=Ralph|date=13 May 2006|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref>
The Getty is involved in a controversy regarding proper title to some of the artwork in its collection. The museum's previous curator of [[antiquities]], [[Marion True]] (hired by Frel), was indicted in Italy in 2005 (along with famed dealer [[Robert E. Hecht]]) on criminal charges relating to trafficking in stolen antiquities. Similar charges have been addressed by the Greek authorities. The primary evidence in the case came from the 1995 raid of a [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]], warehouse which had contained a fortune in stolen artifacts. Italian art dealer [[Giacomo Medici (art dealer)|Giacomo Medici]] was arrested in 1997; his operation was thought to be "one of the largest and most sophisticated antiquities networks in the world, responsible for illegally digging up and spiriting away thousands of top-drawer pieces and passing them on to the most elite end of the international art market".<ref>''[[Men's Vogue]]'', Nov/Dec 2006, Vol. 2, No. 3, pg. 46.</ref> In 2005 True was forced to tender her resignation by the Board of Trustees, which announced her early retirement. Italy allowed the statute of limitations of the charges filed against her to expire in October 2010.<ref>Felch, Jason and Ralph Frammolino (2011), ''Chasing Aphrodite: The Hunt for Looted Antiquities at the World's Richest Museum''. Boston and New York: Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, pp. 265–66, 312.</ref>
In a letter to the [[J. Paul Getty Trust]] on December 18, 2006, True stated that she was being made to "carry the burden" for practices which were known, approved, and condoned by the Getty's Board of Directors.<ref>{{cite news | title = Getty lets her take fall, ex-curator says | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-true29dec29,0,3427365.story?coll=la-home-headlines | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | first1=Jason | last1=Felch | first2=Ralph | last2=Frammolino | date=December 29, 2006 | accessdate=May 5, 2010}}</ref> True is currently under investigation by Greek authorities over the acquisition of a 2,500-year-old funerary wreath. The wreath, along with a 6th-century BC statue of a woman, have been returned to Greece and are exhibited at the [[Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki]].<ref>{{cite news | title = $1.5 mn Macedonian Gold Wreath Attracts Greek Populace | publisher = elitechoice.org | date = March 30, 2007 | url = http://www.elitechoice.org/2007/11/23/15-mn-macedonian-gold-wreath-attracts-greek-populace/}}</ref>
On November 20, 2006, the director of the museum, [[Michael Brand]], announced that 26 disputed pieces were to be returned to Italy, but not the [[Victorious Youth]], which is still claimed by the Italian authorities. In 2007, the Los Angeles J. Paul Getty Museum was forced to return 40 artifacts, including a 5th-century BC statue of the goddess [[Aphrodite]], which was looted from [[Morgantina]], an ancient Greek settlement in Sicily.<ref name="ariel">{{cite news | last = Ariel | first = David | title = Getty to Return Antiquities to Italy | work = [[Forbes]] | date = August 1, 2007}}</ref> The Getty Museum resisted the requests of the Italian government for nearly two decades, only to admit later that "there might be 'problems'" attached to the acquisition."<ref name="povoledo">{{cite news | last = Povoledo | first = Elisabetta | title = In a Tug of War, Ancient Statue Is Symbol of Patrimony | work = The New York Times | date = July 4, 2007 | url = http://travel.nytimes.com/2007/07/04/arts/design/04dig.html}}</ref> In 2006, Italian senior cultural official Giuseppe Proietti said: "The negotiations haven't made a single step forward." Only after he suggested the Italian government "to take cultural sanctions against the Getty, suspending all cultural cooperation,"<ref>{{cite news | title = Getty will return Aphrodite statue if it has origins in Italy | work = [[North County Times]] | date = November 22, 2006 | url = http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2006/11/22/entertainment/art/12_04_5011_22_06.txt}}</ref> did the J. Paul Getty Museum return the antiquities.
In another unrelated case in 1999, the Getty Museum had to hand over three antiquities to Italy after determining they were stolen. The objects included a Greek red-figure [[kylix (drinking cup)|kylix]] from the 5th-century BC, signed by the painter [[Onesimos (vase painter)|Onesimos]] and the potter Euphronios as potter, looted from the [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] site of [[Cerveteri]]; a torso of the god [[Mithra]] from the 2nd-century AD, and the head of a youth by the Greek sculptor [[Polykleitos]].<ref>{{cite journal | last = Slayman | first = Andrew | title = Getty Returns Italian Artifacts | journal = Archaeology | volume = 52 | issue = 3 | date = May–June 1999 | url = http://www.archaeology.org/9905/newsbriefs/getty.html}}</ref>
In 2016, the terracotta head of the Greek god [[Hades]] was returned to [[Sicily]] ([[Italy]]). The archaeological artifact was looted from [[Morgantina]] in the 1970s. The Getty museum purchased the terracotta head of Hades in 1985 from the New York collector Maurice Tempelsman, who had purchased it from the London dealer Robin Symes. Getty records show the museum paid $530,000 for it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Getty Museum to return Hades terracotta head to Sicily|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jan/10/entertainment/la-et-cm-getty-museum-hades-sculpture-sicily-20130110|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Los Angeles - Head of Hades returned to Italy|url=http://www.esteri.it/mae/en/sala_stampa/archivionotizie/approfondimenti/2016/01/los-angeles-restituisce-all-italia.html|website=Farnesina|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref> On December 21, 2016, the head of Hades was added to the collection of the archaeological museum of [[Aidone]], where it joined the statue of [[Demeter]], the mother of his consort [[Persephone]]. Sicilian archaeologists found a blue curl that was missing from Hades' beard, and so it proved the origin of the terracotta head.

Mary Magdalen and John the Baptist by Parmigianino.jpg|[[Parmigianino]], ''Virgin with Child, St. John the Baptist, and Mary Magdalene'', about 1530 File:Titian (Tiziano Vecellio) (Italian - Portrait of Alfonso d'Avalos, Marquis of Vasto, in Armor with a Page - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Titian]], ''Portrait of Alfonso d’Avalos, Marchese del Vasto'', 1533 File:Peter Paul Rubens - The Entombment - 93.PA.9 - J.
